column2: Oh my God! I can\xc2\x92t believe my little brother is married!'
Oh I know!! (Both he and Alice squeal hysterically)'
You guys, why didn\xc2\x92t you tell me you were eloping?'
\xc2\x91Cause it just sorta happened, y\xc2\x92know we were at the\ncourthouse, we were having lunch\xc2\x85'
Wait, wait, why were you at the courthouse? '
We were having lunch. Yeah and then all of the sudden we were like,\n"Hey! Y\'know, we\xc2\x92re here, having lunch let\xc2\x92s get married!'

Wow, a year and a half ago I didn\xc2\x92t even know I had a brother, and\nnow I have a sister too. (They all hug, and Frank and Alice start kissing.) Okay. Okay.\nStop it, don\xc2\x92t. So, I gotta get you a gift now. Is there anything you need?'
Uhh, yeah.'
We\xc2\x92ve been trying to get pregnant, uh pretty much ever since we got\nengaged, we thought we\xc2\x92d get a jump on things, y\xc2\x92know no one\xc2\x92s getting any\nyounger.'
See the thing is umm, we\xc2\x92re not able to y\xc2\x92know, uh, conceive.'
And we\xc2\x92ve tried everything, we\xc2\x92ve seen a bunch of doctors.'

Yeah, and they-and they say that our-that our only chance to have a baby\nis that if they take my sperm, her egg and put it together in a dish and then put it into\nanother girl. So we were wondering if you could be the girl that we could put it into.'
(shocked) That\xc2\x92s a really nice gift. I was thinking of like a gravy\nboat.'
(entering with Ross) Hey! You guys! Check it out, check it out! (He\xc2\x92s\nwearing a blue blazer) Guess which job I got.'
I don\xc2\x92t know, but Donald Trump wants his blue blazer black.'
What?'
Blue blazer back. He-he wants it back.'
But you-you said black. Why would he want his blue blazer black?'
Well, you-you know what I meant.'
No, you messed it up. You\xc2\x92re stupid.'
So what job did you get Joe?'
Oh, ah, tour guide at the museum. Yeah, Ross got it for me.'
Well, how can you be a tour guide, don\xc2\x92t you have to be a dinosaur\nexpert or something?'

No, not really. They give you all the information, it\xc2\x92s uh, it\xc2\x92s\nlike memorizing a script. (Making like a tour guide) "And on your left, you have\nTyrannosaurus Rex, a carnivore from the Jurassic period.'
\xc2\xa0 Great!! That\xc2\x92s great!'
Uh actually Joey, it\xc2\x92s the Cretasous period.'
Yeah but, I can pronounce Jurassic.'
(entering) Hey!!'
Hey!'
Guess what. Frank Jr., and Alice got married!'
Oh my God!!'
And! And, they\xc2\x92re gonna have a baby! (The gang is shocked.) And!\nAnd, they want me to grow it for them in my uterus. (The gang is stunned into silence.)'
My God!'
Are you serious?'
Yeah'
You\xc2\x92re really thinking about having sex with your brother?!'

Ewww! And "Oh no!" It\xc2\x92s\xc2\x97they just want me to be the\nsurrogate. It\xc2\x92s her-it\xc2\x92s her egg and her sperm, and I\xc2\x92m-I\xc2\x92m just the\noven, it\xc2\x92s totally their bun. '
Huh.'
What did you tell them?'
Well, they said that I had to think about it first, but what is there to\nthink about? I\xc2\x92m gonna be giving them the greatest gift you can possibly give.'
You\xc2\x92re gonna be carrying their baby and give them a Sony Play\nStation?'
Honey, this really is an incredible thing to do for them, but there are\nthings to think about.'
Yeah, like you\xc2\x92re gonna be pregnant. I mean pregnant.'
I know!'
Pheebs, you\xc2\x92re talking about putting your body through an awful lot,\nI mean morning sickness, uhh, labour, and it\xc2\x92s all for somebody else!'
Yeah, what\xc2\x92s your point?'
Well, the stuff I just mentioned.'
Wow! I don\xc2\x92t know if I could ever do that. I always figured the\nfirst time I had a baby was with somebody I love and that baby would be a\xc2\x85keeper.'
Y'know you guys were a lot more supportive when I wanted to make denim\nfurniture."
No, Pheebs, listen, if you decide to do this, we\xc2\x92ll be supportive\nlike crazy.'
Yeah.'
We just want you to think it through.'
Yeah, honey, maybe you can talk to somebody who\xc2\x92s had a baby. Like\nyour mom?'
My mom never gave birth. Oh! But my birth mom did.'
Umm, (moves her hand\xc2\x92s down to his butt) I love this touchy. Can I\ntake it to work with me?'
Oh, yeah, sure, it\xc2\x92s not mine anyway. It can with the pants.'
Oh! (They kiss and she leaves)'
I am so jealous.'
You guys are really right\xc2\x85there aren\xc2\x92t you?'
Yes. Right where?'
In the beginning where y\xc2\x92know it\xc2\x92s all sex and talking and sex\nand talking and\xc2\x85'
Yeah, you-you gotta love the talking.'
And the sex?'
All right, we haven\xc2\x92t had sex yet. Okay, what\xc2\x92s the big\ndeal? Y\xc2\x92know? This is special, and I want our love to grow until we move on to the\nnext level.'
Oh, Chandler that is so nice.'
That is really nice\xc2\x85lying! No way is that the reason!'
Why? Just because you\xc2\x92re not mature enough to understand something\nlike that?!'
No, he\xc2\x92s right, I\xc2\x92m totally lying.'
Then what is it?'
Well, Kathy\xc2\x92s last boyfriend was Joey.'
And you\xc2\x92re afraid you won\xc2\x92t be able to\xc2\x85fill his shoes.'
No, I\xc2\x92m afraid I won\xc2\x92t be able to make love as well as him.'
Yeah, I was going for the metaphor.'
Yes, and I was saying the actual words.'
So big deal, so Joey\xc2\x92s had a lot of girlfriends, it doesn\xc2\x92t\nmean he\xc2\x92s great in bed.'
We share a wall! So either he\xc2\x92s great in bed, or she just likes\nto agree with him a lot.'
Sweetie, with you it\xc2\x92s gonna be different. The sex is gonna be\ngreat, \xc2\x91cause you-you guys are in love.'
Yeah?'
Yeah!'
Just go for it Chandler.'
Yeah, you should.'
Yeah, you should, really.'
Go on.'
All right, all right, I\xc2\x92ll go sleep with my girlfriend. But\nI\xc2\x92m just doing it for you guys.'
Okay, now the Mastodon is from the semi-late Jurassic period.'
Isn\xc2\x92t the Mastodon from the Pliocene Epic?'

Shhh! This is a museum, no talking. Right down here, (Motions to a
fossilised dinosaur foot.) we have a large foot. (Sees Ross working in one of the display
cases.) Uhh, and over here we have Ross Geller. (Knocks on the glass) Everyone wave
\xc2\x91Hi\xc2\x92 to Ross. Ross is one of our most important scientists, look at him, hard at
work. (Ross does the old "Putting a cigarette in your ear and pulling it out of your
mouth trick.") Okay, moving right along. Come on.'
It\xc2\x92s open! Come in!'
Hi!'
Hi!'
I\xc2\x92m sorry, I\xc2\x92m late.'
Oh, that\xc2\x92s okay, it gave me time to finish glazing my nipples.'
Wow! You really go all out when you\xc2\x92re expecting company.'
No, I was working on my pottery.'
Oh! Ooh! Oh, I didn\xc2\x92t know that you did\xc2\x85pot.'
Well, yeah, mostly nudes. It combines my two passions, pottery and\nerotica.'
Ooh, erotiery!'
Hey! Okay! Well thanks for coming out to see me. I just-I just\nthought it would be a very good idea to talk about this baby stuff in person.\nY\xc2\x92know\xc2\x85'
Okay.'
I really don\xc2\x92t think it\xc2\x92s a very good idea, Phoebe.'
Why not?'

Well, because you\xc2\x92d be giving up a baby, and I-I really
don\xc2\x92t\xc2\x97I don\xc2\x92t know if there\xc2\x92s anything I can say that could make you
understand the pain of giving up a baby. So, umm, (Picks up a puppy in the box next to the
couch.)'
Oh no! No-no! I understand the pain! Don\xc2\x92t-don\xc2\x92t hurt the\npuppy.'
No-no-no, the-the puppy\xc2\x92s yours.'
Oh, I get a puppy!!'
Well, yeah! I mean yeah, but only for three days.'
Why?'

I realise I don\xc2\x92t have any right to start get all parenty on you
and everything now, but umm, (Sees that Phoebe isn\xc2\x92t paying attention and is busy
mimicking the puppy.) uhh\xc2\x85 Phoebe, would you please look at me and not the puppy,
it\xc2\x92s very important. '
Okay.'

I mean, I know what I\xc2\x92m talking about. I gave up two babies, and
I only wish I had someone there that had given up babies, that could tell me how terrible
it is to give up babies. I just think that, it would be something you will regret every
single day for the rest of your life. So, how ever hard it is to give up this puppy, it
would be like a million times harder to give up a child. (Phoebe is playing with the puppy
again, and not listening) I really shouldn\xc2\x92t have given you the puppy first.'
All right, I\xc2\x92m sorry.'
Uhh, do you mind sitting there. I\xc2\x92m-I\xc2\x92m saving this for my\nfriend Ross.'
You mean Dr. Geller?'
Doctor? Wow! I didn\xc2\x92t know he had a nickname.'
Oh, he won\xc2\x92t sit here. Only the people in the white coats sit\nover there, (Points to there table) and only the people in the blue blazers sit here.'
Well, how-how come?'
That\xc2\x92s just the way it is.'
That\xc2\x92s crazy.'

Maybe it\xc2\x92s crazy in a perfect world, a world without lab coats
and blazers, but you not in a perfect world, you in a museum now. See that scientist in
the classes, he and I used to play together all the time in grade school, but
now\xc2\x85(Turns around) Peter! Hey, Peter! It\xc2\x92s me Rhonda! From PS-129! I shared my
puddin\xc2\x92 which you man! I gave you my Snack Pack! (to Joey) See, he pretend
he don\xc2\x92t even here me!'

I-I think everybody\xc2\x92s pretending they don\xc2\x92t hear you. Anyway,
look, I don\xc2\x92t know about you and your jackets and your separate tables, but Ross is
one of my best friends, and if I save him a seat, I\xc2\x92m telling you, he will sit
in it! (Ross enters and goes over to the white table) Ross! Ross! Over here, man! I-I
saved you seat.'
That\xc2\x92s okay, I\xc2\x92m cool over here. I\xc2\x92ll catch up with you\nlater, Joey. (Joey is shocked.)'
Op, this is saved. (Joey wonders why) Gift shop.'
(entering) Hey, uh, I\xc2\x92m really, really sorry about what happened in\nthe cafeteria today.'
It\xc2\x92s no big deal. Hey, y\xc2\x92know, you do what you gotta do. Right?'
But hey, it\xc2\x92s not just me, I mean the scientists and the tour guides never\nsit together.'
Whatever.'
It\xc2\x92s like that everywhere, Joey! Okay, Mon, back me up here. Where\nyou work the uh, waiters eat with the waiters, right? And the chefs eat with the other\nchefs, right?'
I eat by myself in the alley because everybody hates me.'

Look, Ross, really it\xc2\x92s-it\xc2\x92s no big deal. Y\xc2\x92know you wear a
white coat, I wear a blue blazer, if that means we can\xc2\x92t be friends at work, then so
be it. Y\xc2\x92know, hey I understand. Y\xc2\x92know? Hey, when I\xc2\x92m in a play and
you\xc2\x92re in the audience, I don\xc2\x92t talk to you, right? So it\xc2\x92s y\xc2\x92know,
it\xc2\x92s uh, it\xc2\x92s cool. I\xc2\x92ll see you tomorrow. (Leaves)'
Yeah, when we\xc2\x92re in the audience he doesn\xc2\x92t talk to us, but he\ndoes wave.'
Hi.'
Hey!'
Why is Phoebe singing to Carl Mulden?'
Ooh, y\xc2\x92know what, I think it\xc2\x92s time for puppy to go out again.\nCome on, let\xc2\x92s go to the balcony.'
What?!'
Umm, the street. Come on, let\xc2\x92s go to the street. Ooh, listen,\ndon\xc2\x92t go onto the balcony until after I get back. (Leaves)'
(to Chandler) So, did you do it?'
Yes, yes, we had the sex.'
Uh-oh, it was bad?'
It was fine, y\xc2\x92know? But she didn\xc2\x92t agree with me as\nstrongly as she agreed with Joey. She was more like, "I see you point, I\xc2\x92m all\nright with it."'
Well, it was the first time. Y\xc2\x92know, there\xc2\x92s not always a lot\nof agreement the first time.'
Yeah, not girls anyway, guys agree (snaps her fingers) like that.'

Look, you have to help me! Okay? I mean, I know what to do with a
woman, y\xc2\x92know, I know where everything goes, it\xc2\x92s always nice. But I need to
know what makes it go from nice to, "My God! Somebody\xc2\x92s killing her in
there!"'
All right, I\xc2\x92m gonna show you something a lot of guys don\xc2\x92t\nknow. Rach, give me that pad, please? (She does so and Monica starts drawing on it) All\nright. Now\xc2\x85'
Look, you don\xc2\x92t have to draw an actual wo\xc2\x97whoa! She\xc2\x92s\nhot!'
Now everybody knows the basic erogenous zones. (She starts labelling\nthem) You got one, two three, four (Chandler is shocked to find out there\xc2\x92s more than\nthree), five, six, and seven!'
(shocked) There are seven?!'
Let me see that. (Monica shows her) Oh, yeah.'
(Points to one) That\xc2\x92s one?'
It\xc2\x92s kind of an important one!'
Oh, y\xc2\x92know-y\xc2\x92know what, I was looking at it upside down.'
Well, y\xc2\x92know, sometimes that helps. (She realises what that\ncould\xc2\x92ve meant.)'
(continuing) Now, most guys will hit uh, 1-2-3 and then go to 7 and set\nup camp.'
That-that\xc2\x92s bad?'
Well if you go to Disneyland, you don\xc2\x92t spend the whole\nday on the Materhorn.'
Well you might if it were anything like 7!'
All right uh, the important thing is to take your time, you want to hit\n\xc2\x91em all, and you mix \xc2\x91em up. You gotta keep them on their toes.'
Oo, toes!! Well, for some people. (Chandler eyes her and her toes.)'

All right. Umm, you could uh start out with a little 1, a 2, a 1-2-3, 3,
5, a 4, a 3-2, 2, a 2-4-6, 2-4-6, 4, (Rachel starts getting worked up) 2, 2, 4-7, 5-7,
6-7, 7, \xc2\x857..\xc2\x857\xc2\x857-7-7-7-7-7-7-7-7-7-7-7\xc2\x85(mouths 7)! (They both lean
back on the couch satisfied.)'
Dr. Geller, there\xc2\x92s a seat over here. (Motions to\nan empty chair at the \xc2\x91white\xc2\x92 table.)'
Thank you, Dr. Phillips, but I\xc2\x92m having my lunch at this table, here\nin the middle. I\xc2\x92m having lunch right here, with my good friend Joey, if he\xc2\x92ll\nsit with me.'
(standing up) I will sit with you Dr. Geller. (He goes over to his table\nand they shake hands.)'

Y'know, we work in a museum of natural history, and yet there is something
unnatural about the way we eat lunch. Now, I look around this cafeteria, and y\xc2\x92know
what I see, I see-I see division. Division, between people in white coats and people in
blue blazers, and I ask myself, "My God why?!" Now, I say we shed these-these
coats that separate us, and we get to know the people underneath. (He takes off his coat
and throws it down.) I\xc2\x92m Ross! I\xc2\x92m divorced, and I have a kid!'
(stands up, and throws his coat on the floor) I\xc2\x92m Joey! I\xc2\x92m an\nactor! I don\xc2\x92t know squat about dinosaurs!'
(standing up and removing his coat) I\xc2\x92m Ted, and I just\nmoved here a month ago, and New York really scares me.'
All right, there you go!'
Yeah, you hang in there Teddy!'
I\xc2\x92m Andrew, and I didn\xc2\x92t pay for this pear.'
Okay, good-good for you.'
I\xc2\x92m Rhonda, (motions to her breasts) and these aren\xc2\x92t\nreal! (Joey and Ross look at each other, shocked)'
Wow, Rhonda.'
I\xc2\x92m Scott.'
Yeah, okay, Scott!'
And I need to flip the light switch on and off 17 times\nbefore I leave a room or my family will die.'
My mom\xc2\x92s gonna be here any minute. I can\xc2\x92t do this, I\ncan\xc2\x92t give him up. Yes\xc2\x97no, I can. I don\xc2\x92t want to. But I can. No.'
Oo, I can\xc2\x92t watch this, it\xc2\x92s like Sophie\xc2\x92s Choice.'
Y\xc2\x92know, I never saw that.'
Ooh, it was only okay.'

Ooh, I can\xc2\x92t do this. My mom was right. If I can\xc2\x92t-if I
can\xc2\x92t give him up, then there\xc2\x92s no way I can give up a baby. Ohh, God, Frank and
Alice are gonna be so crushed. What-what else, what else can I give \xc2\x91em\xc2\x97a
kidney!'
(entering with Frank) Hi!'
Hi!'
Uhh, we were just in the neighbourhood, so\xc2\x85'
Yeah, so we just thought we\xc2\x92d stop by and let you know there\xc2\x92s\nstill no pressure.'
None. But if there was something you wanted to tell us, we\xc2\x92re just\ngonna be right over there (points to the counter) having coffee.'
Okay.'
(noticing the puppy) Oh, who\xc2\x92s this little guy?! (Grabs the puppy)'
Oh! Ooh! Umm!'
Oh, he\xc2\x92s so cute, he reminds me of my old dog, Tumour.'
You are so precious, I could just take you home.'
Hey, why don\xc2\x92t you?'
Are you serious?'
Uh-huh, yeah!'
Oh, thanks.'
What are you doing?'

No, I\xc2\x92m really okay with this. Y\xc2\x92know why? \xc2\x91Cause look at
them, and I made that, so\xc2\x85 I know it\xc2\x92s gonna be like a million times harder to
give up a baby but, oh my God, it\xc2\x92s gonna feel like a million times better, right? I
wanna do this. (To Frank and Alice) I wanna carry your baby.'
(shocked) Oh! Oh! Oh! Thank you so much! You don\xc2\x92t know what this\nmeans to us! Oh!'
Oh my God, I think I\xc2\x92m gonna cry!'
It\xc2\x92s gonna be so great.'
(entering) Hi! What\xc2\x92s going on?'
Oh, I-I gave them the puppy and it made them so happy that I decided\nI\xc2\x92m gonna carry their baby.'
But Phoebe\xc2\x85'
No-no-no, I know, but you and I are different people though, and this is\na totally different situation, and I know that I am not gonna regret this.'
Oh, I-I-I understand all that, but it\xc2\x92s just\xc2\x97that was my\npuppy.'
Oh!'
Would you ever be a surrogate for anyone?'
It depends on who asked.'
What if I asked?'
Oh, Mon, sure.'
Really?'
Yes. (Pause) You\xc2\x92re not asking are you?'
No.'
Yes! Totally!'
Oh! Thank you! Thank you! Thank you! Yes! Thank you! (Runs back to\nChandler)'
